Both Castelli and Gualtherus note that the stone had suffered significant damage to the letters. Agustín and Gualtherus report a continuous text with no gaps, but Castelli suggests that two whole lines are missing both before and after the third surviving line of text.
No reliable description of the letter forms is preserved.
193 BCE (if identification of L. Scipio Asiagenus accepted)

1Italicei
2L(ucium) Cornelium Sc[ip]i[one]m
3honoris caussa
Funerary inscription for Marcus Limbricius and his wife Helvia Arura
Latin text preserved in full over four lines, vertically centred on the stone, with a vacat below. The first line is the largest, the third line smallest and most compressed.

The letters are large and simply cut, without serifs. M has hastae of equal length, all off-vertical; S is shallow; R is closed with a long tail extending from the eye; B has small upper eye, closed; V is wide; F has shorter lower bar; E has equal short bars; C is not perfectly curved/circular, but rather shallow. Interpuncts throughout, formed of light vertical strokes.
Antiquarium e sito archeologico di Halaesa

Cadastral inscription for the territory of Halaesa

2nd — 1st century BCE (Kaibel simply 'post-Roman conquest'; Calderone argues 2nd — 1st on letter forms etc. of his frag.; but, 1998, for c. 300 BCE, which Nenci too believes; Manganaro 2nd century BCE).

Halaesa honours Diogenes Lapiron, son of Diogenes
Five lines of Greek text are preserved, with some of the initial letters lost at the left margin.
The letters are plainly and evenly cut, and well spaced, without serifs. Epsilon has a short middle bar, omicron is full size, omega is open.
The text cannot be precisely dated, but the style of the lettering suggests that it belongs to the 2nd century BCE, rather than the 1st.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas
halaesa honours diogenes lapiron, son of diogenes

1[θ]ε̣οῖς πᾶσι
2[ὁ] δᾶμος τῶν Ἀλαισίνων
3[Δι]ογένην Διογένεος
4Λαπίρωνα
5[εὐ]εργεσίας ἕνεκεν
A koinon of priests honours [-?-] Lapiron, son of Diogenes

Three lines of Greek text are preserved: the state of the stone means that the beginning and end of all three lines is lost, and at least one further line could have been lost below. If there were any lines above these, they would have been on a separate block of stone.

The letters are regularly cut, with deep terminations to the strokes rather than extended serifs. Epsilon has a shorter middle bar, detached from the main vertical; omicron is very slightly smaller than the other letters; omega is almost, or completely closed, with a slightly elliptical rather than purely circular form.
Scibona, 2008, La chiesa e il complesso edilizio postmedievale
Scibona, 2009, Decreto sacerdotale per il conferimento della euerghesia a Nemenios in Halaesa
Prestianni Giallombardo, 2017, Un'epigrafe alesina recuperata (IG XIV 354)

Soldiers serving at Eryx honour their commander
Greek text is visible over 10 lines, although much of the initial lines in particular is now lost
Where visible, the letters are plainly and regularly cut, without serifs. Epsilon has short middle bar, omicron is full size, omega is closed and slightly elliptical
Late Hellenistic (period of the Roman Republican province)
Prestianni Giallombardo, 1987, Un'inedita iscrizione tardoantica da Alesa e il problema dell'episcopato alesino

A tessera hospitalis recording xenia between Imulch and Lyson
Four lines of Greek letters, with a consistent left margin, starting at the top of the rear (smooth) side of the tessera, with small vacat below.

Small, slightly irregular letters without serifs. Lunate epsilon, sigma and omega; mu formed by four, equal slanting strokes; omicron generally slightly smaller than other letters; beta is closed, but with separated loops; rho is closed; xsi in form of a Z with horizontal cross bar; kappa has short equal length arms.
2nd century BCE, or possibly 1st century BCE (the letter forms look more plausibly second than 1st century)
Museo archeologico regionale Lilibeo Marsala - Baglio Anselmi

Ampolo, 2012, Compresenza di ethne e culture diverse nella Sicilia occidentale. Per una nuova prospettiva storica
Brugnone, 2024, Lilibeo e il Mare. Il museo archeologico regionale di Marsala
